details.title: Bayesian Analysis of Pareto Reliability With Dependent Masked Data
details.standardTitle: Bayesian Analysis of Pareto Reliability With Dependent Masked Data

p: Ancha Xu is currently a Ph.D. candidate at the School of Finance and Statistics at East China Normal University. His research interest is reliability analysis.

authors.affiliation: Sch. of Finance & Stat., East China Normal Univ., Shanghai, China
authors.name: Ancha Xu

p: Yincai Tang is currently a professor at the School of Finance and Statistics at East China Normal University. He received his Ph.D. in Probability and Statistics in 1999 from that same university. His current research interests include reliability analysis, and empirical finance.

authors.affiliation: Sch. of Finance & Stat., East China Normal Univ., Shanghai, China
authors.name: Yincai Tang

details.abstract: In this paper, we consider a series system with two s-independent components, each of which has a Pareto distributed lifetime. We assume the lifetime data from the system are masked, and the masking probability is dependent. Noninformative prior, and conjugate prior are considered; and Gibbs sampling method is used to obtain the estimators of the unknown parameters, the reliability function, and the hazard function. A numeric example demonstrates how to apply the theoretical results.

citations.title: Bayesian Analysis of Pareto Reliability With Dependent Masked Data

context.text: Ammar & Awad [1] considered the estimation of parameters of the PRM with a given \$\tau\$ when there are masked data.

references.title:
Estimations of parameters in
Pareto reliability model in the presence of masked data
references.text: M. S. Ammar, I. El-Gohary Awad, "Estimations of parameters in Pareto reliability model in the presence of masked data", Reliab. Engng. Syst. Safety, vol. 82, pp. 75-83, 2003.

context.text: Arnold & Press [2] presented Bayesian estimation for the PRM, when \$\tau\$ is known, and \$\theta\$ is unknown.

references.title:
Bayesian inference for Pasreto
population
references.text: B. C. Arnold, S. J. Press, "Bayesian inference for Pasreto population", J. Econometrics, vol. 21, pp. 287-306, 1983.

context.text: [3] presented a general parametric framework that is not restrictive in the number of potential causes of failure, their distributions, or even sampling schemes.

references.title:
Bayesian analysis of competing risks with
partially masked cause-of-failure
references.text: S. Basu, A. Sen, M. Banerjee, "Bayesian analysis of competing risks with partially masked cause-of-failure", Appl. Statist., vol. 52, pp. 77-93, 2003.

context.text: For the determination of hyperparameters, see Berger & Sun [4].

references.title: Bayesian analysis for the Poly-Weibull distribution
references.text: J. O. Berger, D. Sun, "Bayesian analysis for the Poly-Weibull distribution", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 88, pp. 1412-1418, 1993.

links.abstract: The author addresses confidence interval (CI) estimation in a competing risk (or multiple failure mode) framework where sample data are singly time-censored on the right and partially masked. A three-component series system with exponentially-distributed component-failure times is considered in order to represent cases involving full as well as partial masking. The approximate CIs considered are based on: asymptotic-normal theory for maximum likelihood estimators; cube-root transformation of the...

context.text: Doganaksoy [5] presented various methods to find confidence intervals for the three-component series systems with exponential-life components.

references.title:
Interval estimation from censored
and masked failure data
references.text: N. Doganaksoy, "Interval estimation from censored and masked failure data", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 40, pp. 280-285, 1991.

context.text: [6] consider a proportional probability model for a dependent masking probability for the two-component series system.

references.title:
Dependent masking and system
life data analysis: Bayesian inference for two-component systems
references.text: I. Guttman, D. K. J. Lin, B. Reiser, J. S. Usher, "Dependent masking and system life data analysis: Bayesian inference for two-component systems", Lifetime Data Anal., vol. 2, pp. 87-100, 1995.

context.text: To relax the equiprobable assumption, Lin & Guess [7], and Guttman et al. [6] consider a proportional probability model for a dependent masking probability for the two-component series system.

references.title:
System life data analysis with
dependent partial knowledge on the exact cause of system failure
references.text: D. K. J. Lin, F. M. Guess, "System life data analysis with dependent partial knowledge on the exact cause of system failure", Microelectron Reliab., vol. 34, pp. 535-544, 1994.

context.text: The Pareto reliability model (PRM) arises as a mixture of exponential distributions, and its use for simulations with randomly varying environments is amply justified (Lindley [8]).

references.title:
Multivariate distributions
for life lengths of components of a system sharing a common environment
references.text: D. V. Lindley, N. D. Singpurwalla, "Multivariate distributions for life lengths of components of a system sharing a common environment", J. Appl. Probab., vol. 23, pp. 418-431, 1986.

context.text: Lynn & Tae [9] developed a Bayes approach to estimate parameters using the Gibbs sampler, and EM algorithm when the system's components' lifetimes have exponential or Weibull distributions.

references.title:
Bayesian reliability modeling
for masked system lifetime data
references.text: K. Lynn, Y. Y. Tae, "Bayesian reliability modeling for masked system lifetime data", Statistics Probability Letters, vol. 47, pp. 229-241, 2000.

links.abstract: Parametric and nonparametric estimation methods are proposed for reliability characteristics of one failure mode under competing risks with incomplete data; some of the failure times are observed without observing the cause of failure. The efficiencies of these methods are discussed.

context.text: Miyakawa [10] considered the problem of a two-component series system when the system's components have constant failure rates.

references.title:
Analysis of incomplete data
in a competing risks model
references.text: M. Miyakawa, "Analysis of incomplete data in a competing risks model", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 33, pp. 293-296, 1984.

context.text: Under the same assumption, Sarhan [11] obtained the maximum likelihood estimators for the parameters in the two-component, and three-component series systems.

references.title:
Estimation of components reliability
in parallel system using masked system life data
references.text: A. M. Sarhan, A. H. El-Bassiouny, "Estimation of components reliability in parallel system using masked system life data", Appl. Math Comput., vol. 138, no. 1, pp. 61-75, 2003.

links.abstract: Bayes estimation of the parameters and the reliability function based on type-1 and type-2 censored samples from a Pareto failure model is considered. The analysis is extended to situations wherein the exact survival times are not available but only the number of deaths in prescribed time intervals is recorded. Bayes calculations can be implemented easily by means of the Gibbs Sampler.

context.text: [12] developed a fully Bayesian approach to estimate the parameters, and reliability function using the Gibbs sampler, and the rejection/acceptance algorithm.
[12] suggest the prior distribution of \$\log(\tau_{i})\$ to be \$\Gamma(a,b)\$, or \$\tau_{i}\propto constant\$.

references.title:
Bayes estimation for Pareto failure model
using Gibbs sampling
references.text: R. C. Tiwari, Y. Yang, J. N. Zalkikar, "Bayes estimation for Pareto failure model using Gibbs sampling", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 45, pp. 471-476, 1996.

links.abstract: The paper considers the full Bayes analysis of the Pareto distribution when the observations are doubly censored, and provides sample-based estimates of posterior distributions using Gibbs sampler algorithm. The approach is not only computationally simple but fully explores the low-dimensional posterior surfaces-which otherwise seems difficult. Complexities through censored data always arise in life testing experiments; these complexities are no longer problems with the Gibbs sampler algorithm, ...

context.text: Upadhyay & Shastri [13]considered the full Bayesian analysis of the PRM when the observations are doubly censored.

references.title:
Bayes results for classical
Pareto distribution via Gibbs sampler, with doubly-censored observations
references.text: S. K. Upadhyay, V. Shastri, "Bayes results for classical Pareto distribution via Gibbs sampler with doubly-censored observations", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 46, pp. 56-59, 1997.

links.abstract: Life data from multicomponent systems are often analyzed to estimate the reliability of each system component. Due to the cost and diagnostic constraints, however, the exact cause of system failure might be unknown. Referring to such situations as being masked, the authors use a likelihood approach to exploit all the available information. They focus on a series system of three components, each with a constant failure rate, and propose a single numerical procedure for obtaining maximum-likelihoo...

context.text: Usher & Hodgson [14] extended Miyakawa's results to a three-component series system under the same assumption.
In some particular cases, he derived closed-form expressions for maximum likelihood estimates, which extended the results obtained by Usher & Hodgson [14].

references.title:
Maximum likelihood analysis
of component reliability using masked system life data
references.text: J. S. Usher, T. J. Hodgson, "Maximum likelihood analysis of component reliability using masked system life data", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 37, pp. 550-555, 1988.

links.abstract: Analysts are often interested in obtaining component reliabilities by analyzing system-life data. This is generally done by making a series-system assumption and applying a competing-risks model. These estimates are useful because they reflect component reliabilities after assembly into an operational system under true operating conditions. The fact that most new systems under development contain a large proportion of old technology also supports the approach. In practice, however, this type of ...

context.text: Usher [15] considered the case of two-component series systems when the system's components' life times have Weibull distributions.

references.title:
Weibull component reliability-prediction
in the presence of masked data
references.text: J. S. Usher, "Weibull component reliability-prediction in the presence of masked data", IEEE Trans. Reliab., vol. 45, pp. 229-232, 1996.
